name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
text:
—During question time today, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were at their sleight of hand best. I deliberately excluded the Deputy Prime Minister from that statement because his contribution, when asked a question during question time, was not even worth noting. But the Treasurer once again, as he has done on numerous occasions in this place, passed up the opportunity to answer a very simple question. That very simple question went something like this: is the government raising today more revenue from petrol excise and taxes that it was two months ago? Every consumer in this country knows, as we know on this side, the answer to that question is yes. But what did the Treasurer choose to do? He attempted to aggregate revenues from diesel with petrol in a sleight of hand attempt to mislead the Australian people.
Let me turn to the Prime Minister, who I suggest should be the main target in respect of this matter of public importance today. Let us go back to 12 April this year when I asked the Prime Minister a question with regard to petrol. I asked the Prime Minister on that occasion how he expected to meet his pre-election promise that the GST would not force petrol prices to rise and, in particular, I asked him how he planned to meet that promise in Parramatta. While delivering my question on that occasion, I made the point that, on that day at the Mobil service station on the corner of Victoria Road and Macarthur Avenue in North Parramatta, unleaded petrol was 84.9c a litre. I ask members on both sides of the House what they suspect might be the price of petrol today at that same service station in North Parramatta. Would they expect it to be still 84.9c a litre? That is what the Prime Minister would have us believe, according to his answer during question time today. The answer of course is no. Is it 86.9c a litre? No. Is it 90.9c a litre? The answer again is no. The price of unleaded fuel at that same service station—the one I referred to on 12 April this year when petrol was at 84.9c a litre—is today at 94.9c a litre. Yet the Prime Minister wants us to believe that the GST has had no impact on the price of fuel. It is now 10c higher, yet he refuses to answer these simple questions. 
In that same question time in response to a later question on the same issue the Prime Minister said, `Why don't you come back and ask me after 1 July?' Here we are, Prime Minister, well after 1 July and we are putting the simple question to you: how is it you have not been able to meet your election promise? I can only suspect that his answer on that occasion was founded on two things. The first was hope—hope that between that date and 1 July the price of world crude oil would fall enough to make the obvious impact of the GST on petrol prices less obvious. The second was that he had in mind a secret plan—a secret plan that was going to surprise us all, a secret plan that was going to put the critics of his pre-election promise on the canvass. 
Before I go to the PM's secret weapon, let me remind the House why he found it necessary to foreshadow a new initiative with respect to the keeping of his pre-election promise. Having promised that the price of petrol would not rise as a result of the GST, the Prime Minister committed to a reduction of 7c a litre in the price of petrol. He had worked out at that time that for prices up to 77c per litre the arithmetic was such that the 7c reduction would have ensured that petrol need not rise as a result of the introduction of the GST. As I indicated, that theory was okay for prices up to 77c per litre. But for prices beyond 77c per litre the arithmetic changed significantly, and the Prime Minister was left with no choice but to concede that a 7c reduction in the excise on fuel would not be sufficient to meet his pre-election promise. 
I remember the lead-up to 30 June very well. We were all waiting with great expectation. The great question was: would he lift the ante to 7.5c per litre reduction in petrol excise, would he go to 8c, would he go to 8.5c, would he go to 9c? Expectations were very high. But surprise, surprise! The Treasurer came—no, I will not say that the Treasurer came into this place. He did not do that at all.
—He went to Paris.
—I think he was in Paris at the time. Instead, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon of Thursday, 22 June, the Minister for Finance and Administration sneaked out into one of the courtyards in the gaze of the media and announced that the reduction, having conceded that a 7c reduction was not sufficient, would not be 9c per litre at all, that it would not be 8.5c, that it would not be 8c, and that it would not even be 7c. The minister for finance announced that the reduction in fuel excise, to our surprise, would be 6.7c per litre, having conceded that a 7c reduction was not sufficient. You have to ask the question: how could this possibly be? The minister for finance explained on that day that the government had suddenly discovered some embedded wholesale sales tax savings that the major oil companies should be passing on to consumers. They were savings that the ACCC had not identified in its GST pricing guidelines and savings that the major oil companies were quick to denounce, and they produced independent modelling soon after that date that proved inconclusively that there were not significant embedded wholesale sales tax savings to be passed on. 
So the question then is: where does this leave the petrol consumer? It leaves the petrol consumer the victim of the Prime Minister's broken promise—a promise he now attempts to run away from, a promise he now attempts to amend to `need not rise' instead of `will not rise'. The commitment was clear that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise, and it is a commitment that he has repeated on a number of occasions in this place. Where does that leave the consumer? It leaves the consumer in an electorate like mine paying at best, in the better towns where competition is most fierce, around 97c per litre. But where does it leave other consumers in further flung areas around the country? Where does it leave consumers in Queenstown in the electorate of Lyons, who are paying $1.04 per litre? Where does it leave consumers in Launceston in the electorate of Bass, who are paying $1.03 per litre today? How does it affect consumers in Middlemount in the electorate of Capricornia, who are paying $1.09 per litre today? Yes, I can see the adviser noting them down so he can check them later. That is helpful. Where does it leave consumers in Nguiu in the electorate of the Northern Territory, who are paying $1.20 per litre today?  
—One dollar and sixty cents. 
—You changed the town and I forgot to change the price. I thank you for your support—$1.60 per litre. None of those consumers either in my electorate or in the marginal electorates on the other side have any doubt at all why they are paying so much for their fuel. They know that one of the major factors at play here is the impact of the GST on petrol.
What is the GST on petrol? It is a tax on a tax. What has the government done? It has introduced a GST which layers over an existing fuel excise. What does the GST do? The GST causes inflation to rise. What happens when inflation rises? Petrol excise, which is linked to the CPI, also rises. What happens when petrol excise rises? The GST, which lies on top of the petrol excise, also rises. So the GST is a tax on a tax, spiralling upwards. We all know that as the CPI continues to spike and then increase less rapidly petrol excise will continue to rise, as will the impact of the GST. So the Treasurer's answer during question time today should have been a simple yes. The facts are obvious. But instead he sought to attempt to aggregate revenue taken from petrol with revenue taken from diesel excise.
That was not the only announcement that came from the minister for finance on 22 June. The other was some clarification on the government's so-called fuel grants scheme. This is the other initiative taken in a desperate attempt to fulfil the pre-election commitment that petrol prices would not rise. This is the $500 million scheme that will go to people in certain areas—and there are a number of anomalies concerned with that, which have been highlighted here before—where consumers will get a 1c rebate or in some cases a 2c rebate. But we know, and the evidence is already there, that that $500 million of taxpayers' money will do no more than line the pockets of the major oil companies.
There is a history of deceit from beginning to end. The government continue to try to run from the questions during question time when they should be conceding that there is a revenue windfall with respect to petrol prices as a result of the introduction of the GST. They should be admitting as much to the Australian consumer, who knows only too well the impact of the GST on petrol. During question time today the Treasurer raised another matter, that is, Labor's commitment to petrol prices. Labor has got a number of commitments to petrol prices. Again, I am happy to concede that history will show that political parties of all persuasions have, at a number of elections over decades now, made commitments to improve not only the fluctuations in the price of petrol but also the differential that exists between city and country prices. Labor still is committed to doing so, in great contrast to the government which is taking this windfall.
—How?
—The minister at the table, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, asked me a very simple question: how? Firstly, by taking the exact opposite approach to that taken by those who sit opposite. The approach by those who sit opposite is to take $500 million of taxpayers' money and hand it to the major oil companies. The $500 million fuel grants scheme largely goes straight to the major oil companies because they largely run, whether directly or by commission agency, the service stations in this country. Secondly, the government repeatedly endeavour not to curtail the power of the major oil companies—which is the biggest problem in the petrol market—and wind back their ability to manipulate prices and take excessive profits wherever and whenever they can, but to give them more power by deregulating the petrol industry at the retail level. We take a different approach. Firstly, we start from the foundation that the GST is inherently unfair as it applies to petrol. Secondly, we think that power needs to be curtailed. Thirdly, we think there needs to be greater competition not only at the retail level of the petrol industry but also at the wholesale level where the major oil companies have absolute control. I have got a few views on how that can be done. Firstly, introduce more competition at the wholesale level by giving service station operators the opportunity to shop around for their fuel instead of being tied to an exclusive arrangement with one particular major oil company. 
The minister at the table might explain to me why the price of fuel in Muswellbrook in my electorate is consistently lower than it is in Singleton, closer to Newcastle, and Scone, above it, further from Newcastle. It is simply because there is greater competition in Muswellbrook as a result of the entry of Woolworths to the retail market. I suggest to him the best thing he could do is support a proposition to introduce more competition at the wholesale level as well.
—No, that is not what you want. You want to take prices surveillance out in readiness for the arrival of the GST and then concoct figures, as the PM did today, to suggest that it is ridiculous—ask any consumer—to suggest that petrol prices have fallen as a result of the GST. No-one will have that. (Time expired)

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—I am going to go to the parliamentary shop steward and ask that the member for Hunter be given a raise. I think he deserves a raise because he had the good fortune to come into this House after the introduction of the GST, introduce a matter of public importance on the GST and get up in this House and explain the Labor Party's position. What we just heard from the member for Hunter is a major policy statement on the application of tax to fuel. If I heard correctly—and we will check Hansard—the member for Hunter pledged that the Labor Party will abolish the $500 million fuel grants scheme to rural and remote Australia. I asked the member for Hunter what the problem was with the current scheme. He said, `The first thing that we would do is get rid of the $500 million fuel grants scheme to rural and regional Australia.' That was the first thing he said. The member for Hunter pledged it. The Leader of the Opposition was sitting at the table and said nothing. Finally, at last, we have got a snapshot of roll-back. That snapshot of roll-back is that rural and regional Australia will be $500 million worse off because the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy going out to them that started on 1 July ends if the Labor Party ever comes into government. Thank you, I say to the member for Hunter, because you have just given us a snapshot of what roll-back means.
We know the member for Hunter is genuine in circumstances such as this because, as the Treasurer pointed out in question time, when the member for Hunter was interviewed on Hunter Valley 2NM with Chris Lewis on 24 July, the member for Hunter said:
My pledge to my party—
`My party'; that is, the Labor Party—
is this: that petrol prices have been an issue for decades. At every election they become an election issue. But after the election the problem remains no matter who wins.
There is one clear, unequivocal point about petrol prices, and it is this: the most significant impact on petrol prices and the volatility of petrol prices is the volatility of world crude oil. That has the biggest impact on world petrol prices. If you look at the petrol price out of Singapore, which is our main source, you will see that it was $22 a barrel in February last year. Today it is more than $60 a barrel. So, from February 1999 to today, the price of a barrel of unleaded petrol out of Singapore has risen from $22 a barrel to $60 a barrel—and the Labor Party pretends that it has had absolutely no impact whatsoever at the pump!
If you take what the member for Hunter just said—and he said it in front of his colleagues and he said it in front of the Leader of the Opposition—the Labor Party are in fact going to roll back the $500 million subsidy, the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy that is going to people in rural and remote Australia. He pledged that here in this House, in Hansard, and that is a taste of roll-back.
—You already said that.
—I will say it again. And I will say it again because if the member for Hunter and other members of the Labor Party actually make a slip and come into this House and give us some idea of what roll-back means, I say, `Great,' because it is time for those over there to tell the truth. It is time for the Labor Party to start telling the truth. It would have been easy to dismiss this MPI as yet another groundhog day. Here we go again. Another MPI from the Labor Party on the GST. Here we go again. There is one big difference between all of the other MPIs I have done and today: on 1 July the GST started; on 1 July the GST came in, with a raft of other tax reforms that delivered income tax cuts, that delivered higher pensions and that delivered better family benefit payments. On 1 July we abolished the excise, put in place a GST. On 1 July every business in Australia registered for the GST and got 10 per cent cheaper petrol. Every business, every small business in Australia, got 10 per cent cheaper petrol on 1 July. 
—What about the consumers?
—I will tell you about consumers—businesses supply consumers. In the ideal world that the member for Paterson would create the government would be the only supplier of goods and services to consumers—the old socialist rhetoric coming to the fore again, bubbling to the surface. It is a bit like oil in water: it always comes to the surface. In this case, the fact is if business gets it cheaper, consumers get it cheaper. That is how it is delivered. That is how a capitalist economy runs. Business gets it cheaper, price exploitation laws, ACCC powers: consumers get it cheaper—a market economy. Isn't that great? Don't we think that is terrific? That is what we want. That is the sort of capitalist democracy that most Australians want, and that is certainly what those of us on this side of the House find ourselves increasingly trying to protect—protect it from you, the Labor Party. We are trying to protect it from the Labor Party. That is what we are trying to do.
If you are really talking about petrol prices I want to know what roll-back means when it comes to the application of the GST to petrol. I want to know if it means the abolition of the diesel fuel subsidy—24c a litre—which started on 1 July. We heard from the member for Hunter today that it means the abolition of the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy for rural and regional Australia. What does it mean for businesses, all of those businesses out there that get 10 per cent cheaper petrol as a result of the introduction of the GST? What does it mean for those businesses? I will tell you what it means for those businesses: roll-back means that those businesses are going to have to pay more for petrol. Roll-back for those businesses means that they are going to pass on higher costs to consumers. That is what roll-back means.
—GST hasn't given them cheaper petrol.
 (Mr Nehl)—The member for Paterson will have his turn in a little while.
—Thanks to the member for Hunter we have got a snapshot of what roll-back means for petrol prices under the Labor Party. They have already pledged in this House today to increase petrol prices in rural and remote Australia by 1c and 2c a litre. They said it: abolishing $500 million, which the member for Hunter claims goes directly to the fuel companies.
—That's the second time you have run that argument.
—Well, it is a damn good argument, and I will keep running it. And I will tell you why I will keep running it: because it was a slip.
—It wasn't a slip.
—It wasn't a slip? Here I was thinking that for a brief second that Labor had unveiled the curtains on roll-back. I even gave the member for Hunter the benefit of the doubt, and he says across the chamber, `There's no slip. We're just going to abolish it'—$500 million for rural and remote Australia. The member for Hunter has pledged today in the House in front of his leader that they are going to abolish it.
—The member for Hunter has had his turn.
—We are going to come back to this. I feel it coming back over the next few days. I can feel it coming back. Wait a second: question time on Wednesday, question time Thursday. And we have got another two weeks in two weeks time. There is all of next year. We have got a few question times there, a few question times to remind the member for Hunter of his pledge in this House before the Australian people, before his colleagues, to abolish the $500 million subsidy. That is courageous politics! 
And here I was thinking the member for Hunter had a bright career. Here I was thinking that surely Labor caucus would have to accept the advice of the right wing and start putting some right wingers other than just the Victorians into one of their economic portfolios. Here I am thinking, `Gee whiz, the New South Wales Right goes down to the national conference—did you hear this?—and says, "Hang on a sec, all the economic portfolios are occupied by Victorians. They are occupied by Simon Crean, they are occupied by Stephen Conroy, they are occupied by Kelvin Thomson, they are occupied by Lindsay Tanner. We want to put up one of the right wing from New South Wales."' They put up someone from the right wing of New South Wales; they put up the member for Hunter. Now the member for Hunter is expressing economic policy for the Labor Party. I say, `Good on you, Joel. We're there with you buddy. Fight on. We're there with you buddy.'
—Thirteen times, and five minutes to go.
—The minister will address his remarks through the chair, and the member for Hunter will be silent.
—It has taken a hell of a lot of MPIs to find out what roll-back is. It has taken a hell of a lot of debate in this House to get a bit of a picture. It has taken a hell of a lot of time, a lot of rhetoric, a lot of newspaper columns and a lot of hours on talkback radio, but now we are starting to get a picture of roll-back. Now we are starting to get a feel for what it really means.
—The door's just opening.
—It has opened a little. The door has been left a little ajar. It was an innocent question. I was sitting right here. How many questions have I asked generally across the chamber? I sit in this chair and I ask a little question of Simon Crean and I ask a little question of Lindsay Tanner. I ask a whole lot of little questions and there is a little bit of niggling and we never get an answer. Today I pull the one-armed bandit and bingo: I won. It all came down. Now I do not have the arms to carry all the coins—$500 million worth of subsidy in coins.
I would like to thank the member for Hunter for his very generous contribution to this MPI. I think it was genuine; I think the member for Hunter is a pretty genuine guy. It is a legitimate question that the Attorney-General asks: `What has the member for Hunter to say about the surpluses?' We want to know. Do you agree with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the surpluses are going to get bigger? We know what he means by `roll-back'.
—Does the member for Hunter agree that the Labor Party can deliver higher surpluses?
 (Mr Nehl)—The member for Hunter is pushing it uphill.
—He has already pushed and pushed, Mr Deputy Speaker. Keep pushing, Mr Fitzgibbon! We are waiting for Michael Costello to stand outside with a baseball bat. It already has a notch on it for Della Bosca for telling the truth and now it is going to have a notch on it for Fitzgibbon for telling the truth. We have another notch on the baseball bat. It is a real club—it is a big weighty club—and it says, `Anyone who tells the truth, I am going to hit you.' It is a nasty baseball bat because there is a tradition in the Labor Party that if you tell the truth you get caught. In the Labor Party if you tell the truth you get sacked. You get rewarded for telling a fib.
We had the member for Melbourne running around after 1 July saying, `Here is my price survey. It is Armageddon, isn't it? It is terrible out there. There is blood everywhere.' He did not get sacked after it was discovered that he was not telling the whole truth. No, he is still sitting there on the front bench. But Della Bosca comes along and tells the truth and he gets sacked as president of the Labor Party. We are going to watch with interest what happens to the member for Hunter because today he has told the truth. The Labor Party are going to abolish the $500 million subsidy for rural and regional Australia in the form of a 1c and 2c per litre subsidy on every petrol station, on every litre sold in rural and regional Australia, and I say to the member for Hunter: thank you, old mate.

name: Horne, Bob, MP
text:
—Having listened to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation all I can say is that, while he may be a good after-dinner speaker, when he comes into a debate here he either has not read the matter before us or refuses to address it. The copy of the MPI that I have is titled `The failure of the government to deliver on its election promise that the GST will not lead to an increase in petrol prices'. You can interpret that in two ways: it can be a debate about petrol prices or it can be a debate about election promises. Having sat through question time today, I would like to take the tack about election promises.
We know that we have a Prime Minister who cannot utter the words, `I am sorry.' So on behalf of the people of this parliament who want to apologise to the people of Australia, I want to say that I am sorry. I want to say that I am sorry to all those pensioners out there who thought they were going to get $1,000 because they had seen the Prime Minister on television say, `You are all going to get $1,000.' I want to apologise to all those independent retirees who thought they were going to get $2,000. Particularly, I would like to apologise to all of those people in Australia who thought that the price of petrol was not going to rise because they had been assured by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this nation that the GST would not increase the price of petrol—not once and not twice, but many times in this House.
As a matter of fact, the Treasurer is on record last November as trying to explain that you take a certain amount of excise away, you put a certain amount of GST on and the price stays the same. We all know that—the shadow Treasurer mentioned that in question time today. But we all know that in the stealth of night, while the Treasurer indeed was in Paris, 6.7c went off and 8.2c went on. We all know that since 1 July, as petrol prices have increased and therefore the GST component of petrol has increased, the price of petrol is the highest that we have seen it in living memory, particularly in most regional areas. I was particularly interested today to hear that the city-country regional difference is lower. It is lower, there is no doubt about that. I saw an article in one of the weekend Sydney papers that in, I think, Double Bay petrol on Saturday went to 107c per litre. I dare say it was pre-Olympic testing of the market or something like that. But the whole point is that today we saw a disgraceful exhibition from a Prime Minister and a Treasurer of a government that is in denial. They are in denial of promises that they made—try as much as they like to get out of it. We heard the Prime Minister say, `It does not matter whether the term was "would not" or "should not"'. He said, `It did not.' We all know that it did.
The fact is that, since 1 July, petrol pricing has escalated. The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who is at the table, said in the debate today, `I will tell you why petrol pricing got dearer. Crude oil got dearer.' Maybe the minister would like to be reminded of what he said in Hansard. I have a news release from the Australian Automobile Association, which says:
In releasing the latest monthly petrol price monitoring for July, the Australian Automobile Association has expressed disappointment that the Treasurer and the ACCC have not investigated petrol price rises. The latest monitoring shows that despite a fall in world oil prices of $US1 per barrel between June and July, the average July retail price in capital cities rose by about 4 cents per litre.
We have just heard from the minister, the Hon. Joe Hockey, that the price of petrol is related to the escalation in the price of crude oil. The Australian Automobile Association says that the price of crude oil fell by a dollar. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer promised that petrol prices would not, should not and could not rise, but they have risen— hallelujah, brothers, hallelujah!—and the people of Australia want to know why. The word of the Prime Minister can no longer be accepted in this country because it is simply a fact—and everyone knows—that petrol prices have escalated. It has denied the principle that the minister indicated. 
Today in question time the Prime Minister denied that he had promised $1,000 to every pensioner. Anyone who watched the clip on television last night saw him clearly and unequivocally promise $1,000 to every pensioner—they saw him utter those words. He says, `Go back to page 58. Oh, I am sorry, it's page 11.' Why did he say that on television when he was going to have it printed in a book. He knows that the book would be read by a fraction of the people of Australia whereas what was said on television would be seen by the majority of the people of Australia. That is the power of television. 
Again, we come back to the integrity of the government and the honesty of the Prime Minister, and we find that not only do we have core and non-core promises; we have written and spoken promises, which is confusing to the people of Australia. What promises do you believe? I suppose you have core written promises and non-core written promises, and you have core spoken promises. It is just too confusing. Why can't they say what they mean? How can the price of petrol rise when the Prime Minister said in question time today that petrol prices did not go up? Maybe the Prime Minister should go on a tour of Australia and find out what people in regional Australia are paying. 
I can tell you that in Dungog which is only 70 kilometres away from Newcastle, Australia's sixth biggest city, the price of petrol is 103.9c a litre. What is the GST component on high petrol prices for the government? The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Deputy Prime Minister were trying to deny today that this government is not getting a bigger tax take from petrol. We asked that question specifically about petrol. We did not want to know about businesspeople; we did not want to know about people who use diesel; we wanted to know about the ordinary punters like you and me out there who drive petrol cars and use petrol and we cannot claim it off our tax because we do not run a business. That applies to the majority of people who live in rural and regional Australia. They are hurting because of the policies of this government, and this government is denying that that is so. The Prime Minister actually denied that petrol has risen today. Let him go to rural and regional Australia and just find out. Let him go and ask the pensioners that he promised $1,000 to, who are probably driving a leaded petrol car, what they are paying for petrol. He promised them $1,000 that he did not deliver and he promised that petrol would not get dearer—and it did.
Be it about the integrity of government or be it about petrol prices, this government fails on both parameters. Today the government has revealed its arrogance by ignoring what the people of Australia are trying to tell it. They are trying to tell this government that the word of the Prime Minister, be it written or spoken, be it a core or non-core promise, can no longer be relied on. Polls are taken about whether you can trust a politician, but it comes back to the leader of the government, back to the Prime Minister, and he has dodged around telling the truth in the House today. I feel ashamed at being labelled a politician who sits in the same House as he does.

name: Lieberman, Lou, MP
text:
—The last comment of the member for Paterson was that he felt ashamed. It is true that members of the Labor Party should feel ashamed. Let us go through some of the history of fuel pricing in Australia. The cost of fuel in Australia is high because of the Labor government. When the Hawke government was elected in March 1983, fuel excise was just 6.155c per litre. It was twice that by March 1986 under the Labor government; three times that—18c—by the middle of 1986; four times higher by 1990 under Labor governments—it was 24c a litre then; it hit a fivefold increase in 1994 under Labor governments; and, at the time of the 1996 election, fuel excise on unleaded and diesel fuel was over 34c a litre. It is no wonder the member for Paterson felt ashamed, being a member of the Labor Party in this current parliament with that history of his predecessors. 
Of course, the opposition should feel ashamed for another reason. Today, in this very opportunistic debate under the MPI brought up by the opposition, they have ignored the fact that the basic cause of the high price of oil and fuel not just in Australia but in the world is high world prices. They have increased by about 47 per cent to August this year. We did not hear a word from the shadow minister, the member for Hunter, or from his cospeaker, the member for Paterson, about that basic intrinsic fact. If they want to be seen to have credibility in their concern about the cost of fuel in Australia, they first of all have to explain why the Labor Party's policies forced the price of fuel so high for the 13 years they were in government. They also have to explain why they failed in this important debate to explain that the basic cause of increased fuel prices in Australia and in the world is the increase in the world price by about 47 per cent to August this year.
Why didn't they mention that? They did not mention it because they are attempting to do what they were doing before 30 June, when they were predicting the roof would fall in due to the GST in Australia and when they were opposing the GST. Before 30 June, they were distorting the facts, misrepresenting information, concealing material information and trying to cause concern. On 1 July, the sky did not fall in and they are now going to keep the GST. They are humbugs. They said before 30 June that they would not keep the GST and after 1 July they have said they will keep it but they are going to roll it back.
Today we have heard the member for Hunter give an undertaking as shadow minister that the next Labor government in Australia will roll back and take from country people—and I am one of the members of this parliament who represent country people—the 1c to 2c in additional historic grant given by the Howard-Anderson government to rural people, consumers, businesses and others. Let me say this: they will not get away with it. The announcement made today by the shadow minister is that Labor intend to rip off from country people, country motorists and country consumers, the Howard-Anderson grant to rural petrol consumers in Australia of 1c to 2c, amounting to about $500 million per year. But it will not be taken from those people. People are entitled to that allowance and the Howard-Anderson government will ensure that they retain it. We will fight right through to the election to oppose the Labor Party's plan to take it from country people. They will not get away with it.
Furthermore, on the opposition's roll-back position on GST, we in the coalition in city and country will be working closely together to stop the Labor Party—if they become the government—taking from businesses in Australia the input credits that we have been able to give them as part of the major tax reform in this country. In my towns—in Wangaratta, Benalla, Euroa, Wodonga, Bright, Myrtleford, Yarrawonga and Corryong—and in other places, a small business like a plumber with his ute will get about $600 or $700 a year taken off his fuel costs because all the GST in the price of fuel at the bowser in Australia will be rebated to small businesses. It is an input cost. The battlelines are drawn. We are very happy to hear the member for Hunter make these disclosures. We are also very happy to be able to tell the Australian community that in the months leading up to the election we will do all we can to stop Labor getting into power, to stop them taking the input tax credits and the fuel rebate away from small business and to stop them taking away the rebate that John Howard and John Anderson have been able to give—that is, the $500 million to country users of fuel, whether they be in business or not.
Let me just say how sad it was to hear the second speaker for the Labor Party, the member for Paterson, say that he did not want to know about the fuel cost for business and small business. He actually said that today. I say that he should hang his head in shame. We have 900,000 small businesses in Australia. They are the engine room of Australia. They are all over Australia: they are in the country, in the regions and in metropolitan areas. We care about them. But this senior Labor member was backing up his shadow minister on today's MPI by saying, `We don't want to know about the cost of fuel to small businesses.' That is what he said. It is an extraordinary statement. He said, `All we want to know is what it costs for the consumer.' That is a typical example of their narrow perspective and the way in which they try to wriggle and misrepresent policies to people. 
—You just made that up!
—No, I did not. It is the truth. I think the member for Hunter should be relatively quiet this afternoon because he has threatened to take away the $500 million rebate to country people, which he will not get away with. We will not let him get away with it. But now his colleague the member for Paterson says, `We don't want to know about the cost of fuel to business.' The government want people in businesses in Australia to know that they now get an input tax rebate back on the cost of their fuel. Under the major tax reform, the small plumber, the farmer or whoever they are in country or city in Australia will now get the cost of the GST refunded as a business input as a result of the Howard-Anderson tax reforms.
The member for Hunter is the spokesman for small business for the opposition on occasions, and he has an interesting perspective on small business. I often listen to him with interest. I know a bit about his background. I would have thought that he would be rejoicing and saying, `The alternative government takes the view that of all the things in tax reform we will want to respect the fact that for the first time ever businesses in Australia, small, middle and large, will get taken off their fuel the business input, that is the GST component.' But it is not so. They do not want to know about that either.
The MPI today is a shabby attempt to rescue something. I listened carefully yesterday at question time and again today when the Treasurer asked the opposition to indicate their position regarding roll-back, surplus and GST. There was silence. Obviously, what has happened is that the Labor Party are desperate for strategy. They say, `We have to cobble something together. Fuel is an emotional issue. Fuel prices have gone up. We know it is mainly due to world price movements and other things, but we will get poor old Joel, the member for Hunter, and we will use him. We will whack him in the House and try to concoct this motion and this emotional argument.'
The opposition have been caught out because they cannot deny the fact that fuel prices have increased—not only in Australia but also worldwide—by 47 percent up to August this year. Now do you deny that? Why didn't you say that? You have lost your credibility. If you want to come into this House and talk about reforming fuel, the Hydra-headed monster, you have to be fair dinkum. You have to put all the facts on the table, not the piecemeal stuff, not the opportunistic stuff, as you have tried to do today. It is to your eternal shame that you have done that and missed the opportunity to have a decent debate on the other issues regarding competition that we can work together on. The opposition in the Senate have got together to stop the government's further reforms with respect to fuel in Australia. There is a story to be told there which they will have to account for at the next election. The MPI is a sham. It is a cheap, opportunistic trick to try and plug into the emotion caused by high fuel prices around the world and it should be rejected out of hand. (Time expired)

name: Andren, Peter, MP
text:
—I rise today to speak on several aspects of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000. I support those elements which amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in so far as they go, namely, to adjust grants for funding year 2001 for price movements and varying grants to reflect revised estimates for the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. However, I wish to challenge some of the contentions made in the minister's second reading speech. Despite the rhetoric about quality education and research, I am mindful of anecdotal information from the university sector that suggests the story is very different on the campuses. We have heard elsewhere in this debate how student-staff ratios have increased by 33 per cent in recent years, while infrastructure is suffering and the market driven approach to tertiary education has seen a devaluation of the classics and arts in our university education. Institutions now receive operating grants on the basis of their planned student load. The receipt of higher education contributions will increase by 113 per cent between 1996 and 2002, which will enable a decrease in Commonwealth funding by 12 per cent over the same period.  
While the Commonwealth provided an equivalent of the up-front HECS payment for each HECS-only undergraduate enrolled above a target level from 1998, this has nevertheless not eased increasing pressure on university infrastructure and resources. Funding per actual equivalent full-time student units has decreased from $13,388 to $12,499 in the last 16 years, 1983 to 1999, according to the Bills Digest. The minister speaks of the remarkable achievement in increasing undergraduate places by 35,000, reflecting this government's policy of making higher education more accessible to all Australians. But quantity alone will not deliver Australia the clever, new economy people that we need. It certainly will not deliver the teachers, the writers, the artists, the musicians, the anthropologists or the journalists that a civilised society as opposed to a smart society requires.
In my electorate there are two universities, the University of Sydney, Orange Campus, and Charles Sturt University, Bathurst. Both deny that the government has maintained funding as is claimed. The universities need growth and there is no funding guaranteeing this. For instance, Charles Sturt University needs to expand its campus in Dubbo but has to fund within its current student number intake. As well, extra resources for academic salaries have to be found from within current funding. Salaries are not supplemented. The universities had to meet increased salary expectations—in Sydney University's case about 17 percent and for other universities around 12 percent.
I am told that in the past five years salary increases have accounted for 25 per cent of the increase in university expenditure at a time when student undergraduate numbers have increased, as the minister says by 35,000. You cannot cram more and more people onto a bus without crowding, reducing the quality of the trip and frustrating all aboard, especially when there is no attempt to improve the conditions or the motor to get the thing to where you want to go. I heard contributions to this debate outlining the ridiculous size of some tutorial groups and I can vouch for that from information I have received from students I know. We are losing academics overseas, and there is little incentive to attract top people when the emphasis is on quantity of graduate output, not quality. Indeed, as figures this week suggest, the UAI intake is set significantly lower for cashed-up students compared with those who can only afford an education under HECS. This is a gradual undermining of quality in order to generate quantity at the expense of our nation's knowledge stock.
This bill is also supposedly providing additional funding for research. I note the comments of the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee which state that the OECD figures on which the government based its knowledge and innovation policy statement last year were outdated and that there is a need for major additional investment in research. The AVCC claims that Australia's higher education research and development expenditure is falling. But I note that the research paper on this bill shows that, in 1998 figures, the higher education research and development expenditure to GDP ratio has increased marginally from 0.43 in 1996 to 0.44 in 1999 and compares more than favourably with Germany, USA, France and Canada. But there is no reason to be complacent. Those other countries enjoy a huge comparative advantage in economic muscle. If we do not want to be marooned on an island between the developed and underdeveloped nations, we must take the research and development lead of a smaller nation like Finland which has a research to GDP ratio approaching 0.6. To the extent this bill improves research funding it is to be welcomed, but I suggest we need to be far bolder and, again, not wait for the market to pick up the tab.  
I now want to comment briefly on another aspect of this bill as it pertains to the regional health package. As we know, there is a wide difference between regions in the ratio of general practitioners to population. Whereas there are about 125 GPs per 100,000 population in capital cities, there are 95 GPs or thereabouts per 100,000 in small rural areas. The difficulties of attracting doctors to rural towns are well documented. 
In recent times in my own town of Molong, there was much concern when one of the two GPs left town. After the local community banded together and discussed the issues, the shire council agreed to invest ratepayers' money in the doctors' surgery, which is rented out to the new doctor. The community, like that at Condobolin and more and more in other places around regional Australia, is having to invest its own money into the infrastructure needed to attract doctors to a town, if they are lucky enough to find a doctor. The irony in this case is that the doctor who came to town left another rural community further west, and I doubt that vacancy has been filled.
It is encouraging to see $32.4 million allocated for the 100 bonded scholarships of $20,000 per year for students who make a commitment to practise in rural areas for six years. The Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, under which this bill is framed, will be responsible for $14.8 million of this amount. The hope in all of this is that, after five years, there will be an additional 500 medical students who will eventually be practising in rural areas, studying at Australian universities—a bold plan, a bold hope, but I have real doubts it will come true. 
I note that the Australian Medical Association has withdrawn its support for this scholarship scheme. Having initially supported and, in fact, pressed the government to introduce just such a scheme, the AMA is now a strong critic. According to Dr Shane Sondergild, speaking for the AMA on ABC AM on 31 July, students would be `crazy' to sign up for periods up to 18 years, not just the six years of the bond. Dr Sondergild says students would have to sign up for six years when they are students, with six years study ahead of them followed by possibly another six years worth of training on top of that. If the student reneges, they are penalised from obtaining a provider number, as Dr Sondergild says, for 12 years. Who would accept a deal like that? 
A few months earlier, in May, the then President of the AMA, Dr David Brand, warned: 
You could be a very old person before you finish this. To commit somebody to something that far in advance wasn't how we saw it happening. 
The government, through the department, argues that the scheme is deliberately designed to keep doctors in rural areas for many years. First Assistant Secretary to the Department of Health and Aged Care, Bob Wells, told the Sydney Morning Herald, `The more exposure people have to rural practice the longer they will stay.' That is a very bold statement from Mr Wells, because doctors alone in a rural community are not going to stay there for very long without the sort of infrastructure, including nursing support, around them. It may be all very well to say that doctors would stay in a rural community, providing there is the back-up of locums, access to local hospitals and education opportunities for the kids, but to just boldly state rural exposure is enough to keep doctors in the country is wildly optimistic. 
I have long stated that the only way to ensure experienced doctors are made available to rural communities is through the allocation of Medicare provider numbers to communities of viable patient catchments. The minister argues that this is unconstitutional and that doctors cannot be conscripted. I suggest that it is simply the marketplace in operation. There is no compulsion on any doctor to go to Molong or Wellington or Condobolin or wherever a vacancy exists, but that is where the Medicare provider number is located if a doctor wishes to relocate. Under such a plan, there are a finite number of Medicare provider numbers, with a certain number held for allocation to communities. After, for instance, six or 10 years, the doctor could move wherever he or she chooses with a Medicare provider number, and another number is allocated to that community if an already number-provided doctor is not available to fill the vacancy.  
Surely, this is a simpler and more cost-effective way of ensuring that we have doctors in rural communities, for isn't the bond scheme a form of conscription anyway? It is a very imprecise way of delivering doctors to the bush given the long time frame involved in actually seeing a doctor on the ground. That time delay alone will not address the rural doctors' shortage crisis which is a now problem, not a 12 years down the track one.
By the way, while we are dreaming up schemes to get doctors into the bush, what about the shortage of nurses and physiotherapists? Surely a bonded scholarship scheme for nurses, physiotherapists and those who are allocated community provider numbers, along with a package of incentives such as zone allowances, makes more sense in the short term than these doctor scholarships. Despite these strong reservations about the direction tertiary education is headed in this country and the flaws in this particular bonded scholarship scheme, it would be churlish of me to reject the bill. However, I note the opposition's second reading amendment, and I support its sentiments.

name: Worth, Trish, MP
text:
—In summing up this legislation, I would like to thank everybody who has contributed to the debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 and I also table a replacement explanatory memorandum. It simply contains a little more information than did the earlier memorandum. Some weeks have passed since the commencement of this debate in respect of this legislation, during which time the Labor Party has held its annual conference in Hobart. This is where we were promised real policy from the Australian Labor Party, but in fact we got only slogans—no detail, nothing for regional Australia. Given Labor's talk about a knowledge nation, it is important for the shadow minister and other speakers to be knowledgeable about this legislation, for a start. If the shadow minister wants to talk about knowledge, let us start by separating fact from fiction. To do so I will deal with each of his claims individually while at the same time informing the House.
The shadow minister claims that $1 billion has been cut from university operating grants. The amount available for total operating grants increased in real terms between 1996 and 2000 from around $5 billion to just over $5.1 billion. Funding, including HECS, per fully funded student place has also increased in real terms under this government from $11,600 in 1995 to $11,800 in 2000. This government is also partially funding student places that universities choose to provide above the number of Commonwealth fully funded places. The previous government did not fund overenrolments. Funding for overenrolled places in 1999 amounted to $49.5 million and meant a further 26,000 places for which universities received funding. Most importantly, the policies of this government have allowed universities to develop more diverse and sustainable funding bases. In 2000 it is estimated that the total revenue available to higher education institutions from all sources will be a record $9 billion, around $900 million more than was available to universities in 1995.
I compliment the member for Groom for his contribution to the debate; his pride in his electorate and in the University of Southern Queensland was very evident. The University of Southern Queensland, which the member for Groom spoke about with such authority and such knowledge, is an excellent example of a university which has taken advantage of the policies of this government to become a leader at the national and international level in exporting education to the world and, in the field of distance education, winning prestigious national and international awards for excellence along the way. 
The shadow minister claims that the government has had a $3 billion education deficit. The shadow minister must have sent out notes to all the other speakers from the other side. I say to all of them: this claim does not stand up to scrutiny. In relation to higher education, total funding provided for university operating grants has risen in real terms during the government's term in office from $5 billion in 1996 to $5.1 billion, as I have already said, in 2000; and funding per fully funded student has increased, as I have also mentioned, from $11,600 in 1995 to $11,800 in 2000. In 2000 the government will spend $402 million more on schools than Labor did in its last year of office, and that is a 26 per cent increase. So much for the so-called slashes to education!
Commonwealth spending on education is around 2.2 per cent of gross domestic product, the same as it was in 1994-95. The high level of economic growth experienced under this government means that Commonwealth expenditure on education is in fact 17 per cent higher in real terms. The Labor Party has misrepresented the realities of the Commonwealth expenditure on education by ignoring the fact that Austudy payments of around $1.25 billion have been transferred to the social security and welfare portfolio.
This government has provided greater educational opportunities. It has continued to focus on providing opportunities for young people seeking their first qualification after leaving school. We are continuing to increase the number of fully funded undergraduate places. The number of these places rose from around 364,400 equivalent full-time places in 1999 to 365,920 in 2000. Since 1995 the number of fully funded undergraduates has increased by more than 19,000 equivalent full-time places. In addition, as already mentioned, this government is partially funding overenrolled student places.
The shadow minister claims that the 2000 budget contained only $17 million in extra funding for education this financial year and that there is only $62 million over four years in the government's budget forward estimates. The shadow minister is quoting very selectively from the budget papers. If he had counted all new funding for education, he would see that the total is actually $271.4 million over four years—more than four times the amount quoted by the member for Dobell. The shadow minister claims that the government has cut $171 million in funding from regional universities, including $16 million from James Cook University.
The aggregate total operating grant for the universities named by the shadow minister has in fact increased in real terms by $34 million between 1995 and 2000. This government provides over $1 billion and 100,000 equivalent full-time undergraduate opportunities a year to regional universities and Australian students in the region. Between 1996 and 2002 the government has allocated $140 million for physical and electronic infrastructure development in regional universities, and a further $19 million to assist regional universities seeking to make changes to their operations and electronic communications and to strengthen their regional campuses. Last year an extra 7,431 rural and isolated students accessed higher education, compared with the last year of Labor in office.
The white paper on research entitled `Knowledge and Innovation' announced a regional assistance package to enable universities to strengthen their regional connections, foster a shift towards a more entrepreneurial approach, concentrate research activities into areas of strength and ensure that regional communities receive the full benefits offered by new fields of research. The package provides for a $6 million dedicated fund to support the research and research training activities of regional universities and assist their transition to the new funding system, and $10 million a year for collaborative research on issues of benefit to regional communities. On 20 July 2000 the minister announced funding of $1.6 million from the Higher Education Innovation Program for additional bandwidth for six regional universities. Those universities are James Cook University, Central Queensland University, University of Southern Queensland, Southern Cross University, the University of New England and the Northern Territory University. 
The shadow minister claims that we are facing a crisis in research and that public funding of research has declined. This claim cannot be supported in fact. Australia's expenditure on higher education research and development increased by 13 per cent between 1996 and 1998—just $2.6 billion. Higher education expenditure on research and development as a percentage of gross domestic product increased to 0.44 per cent in 1998 compared with 0.34 per cent in 1990. On these figures, Australia ranks fourth amongst Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries in expenditure on higher education research and development as a proportion of gross domestic product—higher than the United States, Germany, Japan, Canada and the United Kingdom.
We have a strong base of government spending on research. The government increased funding for medical research in the 1999-2000 budget, providing an additional $614 million over six years. Funding for targeted research programs administered by the education portfolio will total $452 million this year—up from $441 million in 1999 and $411 million in 1996. The government acknowledges that, although our public sector research funding is strong, Australia has a low level of private sector expenditure. The tax changes, including reductions in capital gains tax rates announced in September last year, will improve the financial incentives for industry to invest in research. The government's white paper `Knowledge and Innovation' also encourages industry-university collaboration.
The shadow minister claims that James Cook University has lost $16 million from funding cuts. I thank the member for Herbert for outlining in his speech this government's support for James Cook University. I would like to add the fact that James Cook University's operating grant has increased between 1996-2000 by some $5 million in real terms. This is largely due to funding for growth places and the new medical school. James Cook University's operating grant is now over $87 million. Since this government came to office, 670 new fully funded places have been made available to the James Cook University to 2002. After six years some 360 places will have been provided to the new medical school.
This government restored the growth places previously allocated for 1997 and 1998 which were withdrawn from the university in 1997 because it did not meet its agreed undergraduate enrolment levels. In addition, this government has provided some $17 million from the capital development pool for the development of the university's Cairns campus in recognition of the strong demand in the region. The university will also receive $3 million in 2002 for a health science and sciences precinct at the Cairns campus. The precinct will increase the university's ability to offer courses in health related disciplines and will complement the activities of the new medical school being developed in Townsville. In 1998 the university was allocated $1.39 million over four years under the restructuring and rationalisation program for the development of computer network and videoconferencing facilities and information technology laboratories. This is in addition to $1.322 million to be provided in 2002 from the capital development pool for a collaborative proposal providing bandwidth access being developed by the Queensland Office of Higher Education.
Turning to regional health, the shadow minister welcomed the government's initiative to fund bonded medical scholarships to put more doctors into regional Australia, but he claims that the idea has been stolen from the Labor Party policy. This begs the question: where is this policy? Also, what did the Labor Party do about regional health policy and care when it had the opportunity to do something? This government is the first to seriously address the availability of medical services in country and remote Australia. The government's $560 million country health package is the largest effort yet by an Australian government to address the rural health issues and address the historic imbalance between rural and city health. It should be noted that the package builds on the $200 million in funding that was provided two years ago. 
The member for Bradfield spoke of what it was like to be a general practitioner in the country and read Dr Leanne Rowe's sensitive and revealing account of her own experiences. I am pleased that he mentioned Dr Leanne Rowe. She has been of significant help to young people in Australia in as much as she has been prepared to work with me and a reference group and be part of an expert panel, in fact, advising parents and the wider community on drug education for young people in schools and, of course, on all the types of problems they encounter, and advising parents and others of how they might help.
It goes without saying: the more general practitioners there are in the country, the lighter the load will be for those who currently work in rural Australia. I was disappointed that the member for Calare spoke about the here and now. Of course, the here and now is always important, and this government has taken steps to address that. But we must have a government that also has the courage to plan for the future and to succeed in having those services provided throughout the country.
The shadow minister made other claims, such as the claim that indexing HECS debts for inflation is `an unfair and retrospective slug'. The fact is that an indexation factor has always been applied to a person's outstanding HECS debt on 1 June each year. The calculation is based on the movements of the all groups consumer price index. This has been the case since the inception of HECS, which of course was introduced by the Australian Labor Party. The purpose of indexation is simply to maintain the real value of the debt. In real terms, students will repay only what they borrowed and will continue to repay their HECS loan based on their capacity to repay.
With the tax cuts given under the new tax system, a graduating student starting out on a salary of $28,000 will receive a tax cut of $762 per annum. It should be noted that HECS is not subject to GST. HECS repayment thresholds, which are adjusted each year to reflect changes in average weekly earnings, will also not attract the GST. In addition, student allowances such as Austudy and the youth allowance rose by four per cent from 1 July 2000, and rental assistance rose by 2.5 per cent. The government has also provided subsidies for textbook retailers to discount textbooks for students by up to eight per cent.
As a government, we are concerned about all young people, whether they be in training, apprenticeships or higher education. Young people who work often earn a low income, yet they still pay their fair share of taxes. It is not right that these young people through their taxes subsidise the education of others who stand to gain lifelong benefits as a result of their participation in higher education. As was argued by the member for Bradfield, the Australian Labor Party is really claiming that those on low incomes should subsidise those who will earn higher incomes. The government considers the current HECS arrangements to be a fair and appropriate contribution by students to the cost of their education given the undoubted personal benefits they will derive, particularly higher average wages over their lifetime. The shadow minister makes the point that the students receiving non-government tax-free scholarships will not have their scholarships increased by the government. It is clearly a matter for the organisations which fund scholarships to determine the value of those scholarships. If these organisations wish to maintain the value of the awards, then it is their responsibility to index them.
The shadow minister makes the claim that the government is attempting to impose pattern bargaining on universities by offering funding for salary supplementation to universities making genuine reforms to industrial and management practices, reforms that are needed to enhance the flexibility and responsiveness of universities to students and the community. One of the reasons the government has introduced the workplace reform program is to counter the pattern bargaining tactics of the National Tertiary Education Union, which is undermining the quality and efficiency of Australian universities. The effect of the industrial tactics adopted by the National Tertiary Education Union is to hinder enterprise specific bargaining, thus denying universities the opportunities to become more efficient and to generate revenue.  
Specifically, the National Tertiary Education Union has issued instructions mandating 19 per cent salary increases across the sector, mandating the incorporation of non-simplified industrial awards in the sector, mandating uniform workload standards across faculties which means that universities are unable to tailor conditions to the needs at the local level, mandating restrictions on contracting out and prohibiting the negotiation of redundancy and deployment provisions. In its negotiation instructions, the National Territory Education Union has insisted on compulsory standard claims and forbids agreements which either do not contain the mandatory issues or contain concessions to the employer which have been prohibited.
Where an agreement does not meet the National Tertiary Education Union's directives, the national office of the union has shown itself prepared to overrule its own branches at a local level which have on occasions been prepared to adopt a more flexible approach to enterprise bargaining. For example, at the University of Southern Queensland, the local branch of the National Tertiary Education Union entered into an agreement with the university, but this was overruled and subsequently rejected on the advice of the national body. The member for Bradfield spoke about the supposed education policy of the Australian Labor Party and how it truly fails the knowledge nation test, firstly, by sacking Barry Jones and, amongst other things, deriding those who follow intellectual pursuits.
It is important to understand what this bill is really all about. This bill includes a number of technical areas which reflect no change to government policy—namely, this bill updates the funding amounts of the Higher Education Funding Act to price supplementation for price movements and reflects revisions to the estimates for HECS contributions and expenditure on the workplace reform program. The bill establishes the base level of funding for universities in 2002 and provides for the relocation of unspent funds from 1999. Members will be pleased to note that the government will carry over funds of $4.7 million. They will not be lost.
Further on the technical side, this bill allows for the name change of Batchelor College in the Northern Territory to the Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education and amends the definition of `year to which this act applies'. Very importantly, this bill also contains a number of new measures which are substantive.
As the members for Herbert, Groom and Bradfield so eloquently said, an extremely important component of this bill is part of the government's $562 million country health package. (Extension of time granted) As my colleagues said, this is the largest effort ever by an Australian government to redress the imbalance between country and metropolitan health services. This government is creating an extra 100 places for medical students a year at a cost of $32.4 million over four years, in addition to the current 10,300 medical students studying in Australian universities. These additional medical students will be committed to practise in rural Australia for six years. The reality and the good news is that in five years time there will be 500 additional medical students studying in Australian universities who will eventually practise in rural areas. The pressure then on doctors like Dr Leanne Rowe will consequently be reduced. This news is welcomed by both country and city dwellers, as the health of the nation is important to all Australians. This government is the first to recognise the needs of people living in the country and the first to take action to do something about it.
This bill reflects the government's commitment to knowledge and industry. It reflects good policy and encourages university and industry collaboration across the academic, industry and community sectors by boosting funding by an additional $79 million for the Strategic Partnerships with Industry Research and Training Scheme and the Research Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities Scheme. This additional funding will provide more research opportunities for students and researchers. It will encourage research and interaction between industry and academics who, by working together, will help ensure good outcomes for students and industry and see that Australia keeps up with the rest of the world. The measures contained in this bill will help develop Australia's higher education system and create a financially responsible and viable system of education which meets the needs of students and the community as a whole. I would like to foreshadow that I will move a government amendment to this bill in the consideration in detail stage that will further increase the funding available for universities from next year.

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
We are considering today opposition amendments to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 1998. These amendments remove from that bill those provisions relating to the imposition of charges that would have been imposed by the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Charges Bill 1998. The charges bill was rejected in the Senate with the support of the opposition and the Democrats.
The government cannot understand what the opposition hope to gain by opposing the charges bill and the complementary amendments contained in the amendment bill. As I said in the previous debate on the bills in the House, the government does not believe that it is either fair or appropriate to use public funds to subsidise businesses involved for commercial gain in the production or distribution of publications, films or computer games. The government does not think it is at all unreasonable that the industry should be expected to pay for the services and benefits it receives from the national classification scheme.
The charges that were to be levied by the charges bill were designed to cover the cost of activities ancillary to the classification services provided by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. These include certain research, the community liaison officer scheme, policy development and ministerial support. While these activities are related to an efficient and effective classification and enforcement scheme, for constitutional reasons their cost cannot be included in the fees for the provision of classification services. They nevertheless benefit industry. For example, the community liaison officer scheme, which now operates in all jurisdictions, is designed to increase compliance with the classifications scheme which benefits those sectors of the industry that do comply with the law. Policy development and research assist in improving consistency in decision making and in ensuring that classification decisions reflect community standards. 
The government is aware that sections of industry have expressed concern about the effect of the 1997 classification fee increases and the further increases that were proposed under the charges bill on the availability of material that has a limited market appeal in Australia. In response, the government considered that there is a case to enable certain material, where limited distribution is involved, to be classified at reduced rates and has taken action as a consequence. First, the amendment bill empowers the Director of the Classification Board to waive, in whole or in part, classification charges for `limited distribution special interest material' which comprises a documentary record of an event or which is of a cultural or like nature, if it is in the public interest to do so.
Secondly, the government proposes to further expand this power in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 by empowering the director to waive fees for short films from new or emerging film makers. This means that films of this kind which would usually fall outside the exempt categories will still need to be classified but that the fee for doing so can be waived or reduced.
Thirdly, the amendment bill (No. 2) 1999 proposes that the current exemptions in the act be expanded to cover current affairs, hobbyist, sporting, family, live performance, musical presentations and religious films. These will be an addition to the current exemptions in the act, which cover films for business, accounting, professional, scientific or educational purposes. Films within these proposed new exempt categories are typically distributed to a specialised market, often in relatively small numbers. Removing the need for them to be classified should ensure their continued availability and thereby contribute to product diversity in the Australian market. The combined cost to revenue of these measures is estimated to be $354,000.
The government believes that its response to concerns about the effect of the increase in classification costs on certain industry sectors has been both timely and responsible and that it should address many of the issues that have been raised. Given these factors and the fact that the industries which are embraced by the national classification scheme have a high turnover each year, the government can see no justification for the stance the opposition has taken on the charges bill and on the complementary amendment bill we are considering today. 
Just to reinforce the impact that the opposition's actions are having, the industry bodies consulted in the course of preparation of the scheme, who represent those who will benefit from the opposition's action, include members of the Motion Picture Distributors Association, which represents the large cinema studios. (Extension of time granted) It also includes members of the Australian Visual Software Distributors Association, which represents major video and computer game distributors; members of the Eros Foundation, which represents the adult industry; and, since its formation in August 1997, members of the Australian Independent Distributors Association, which represents independent film distributors in Australia.
The rejection by the opposition and the Democrats of the charges bill in the Senate leaves the government with no real alternative but to accept the Senate amendments to the bill. It does so with great reluctance. The stance of the opposition and the Democrats will only increase the burdens on the public purse to the benefit of commercial operators.

name: McClelland, Robert, MP
text:
—The opposition accepts the Senate's amendments. I should indicate that the fact it was necessary for the government to propose a separate charges bill, in the form of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Charges Bill 1998, was an acknowledgment that it amounted to a tax rather than the recovery of the cost of classifying films. As the Attorney-General acknowledged, that was to recover the cost of matters which were ancillary to the classification task, including research, policy development, ministerial support and some payment for enforcement. 
We say that there is a public interest in the classification regime operating efficiently by denying access to improper or inappropriate material by households and ensuring classifications are in place so that people know the nature of material before they purchase or rent it. We thought it was inappropriate to burden the industry with those additional or ancillary items. In forming that view, we had regard to the fact that the smaller producers were going to be penalised by those additional charges—that is, not the actual disbursement involved in the classification process but those additional public policy considerations. In particular, whereas the larger producers and publishers can spread the cost of classification over a much broader market circulation, the smaller or, if you like, niche producers do not have that opportunity, yet the classification charge would have been rendered in respect of the length of the movie or video or the size of the publication rather than the circulation. We believe that would have had greater adverse effects on smaller producers.
We are also mindful of the real risk. There have been some suggestions that, since higher charges were introduced in 1997, the amount of unclassified material has increased as a result of backyard operators not complying with the legal processes required in respect of classification. That of course presents not only the potential for social harm in terms of this material being purchased and entering households but also a problem for those legitimate producers and publishers who are doing the right thing. For instance, we saw it as inequitable to charge those legitimate producers and publishers who were doing the right thing for the cost of enforcing the system against those who were acting illegally.
Moving on to the issues, we support and welcome the ability to grant exemptions for those publications which are of a documentary or cultural nature. We say that is something to be encouraged. We also support the additional points of clarification which will clarify the prosecution procedure and the ability to obtain prosecutions of those publishers and producers who are not complying with the law. So, in short, the opposition supports the bill as amended by the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
